items.content_html:
To be human is finally to be a loser, for we are all fated to lose our carefully constructed sense of self, our physical strength, our health, our precious dignity, and finally our lives. A refusal to tolerate this reality is a refusal to tolerate life, and art based on the empowering message and positive image is just such a refusal.

â€”Mary Gaitskill, Somebody with a Little Hammer: Essays

items.content_html:
â€œThe Social Life of Forests,â€ in the New York Times, is my favorite science long read in a very long time. Fascinating.

An old-growth forest is neither an assemblage of stoic organisms tolerating one anotherâ€™s presence nor a merciless battle royale: Itâ€™s a vast, ancient and intricate society. There is conflict in a forest, but there is also negotiation, reciprocity and perhaps even selflessness.

> An old-growth forest is neither an assemblage of stoic organisms tolerating one anotherâ€™s presence nor a merciless battle royale: Itâ€™s a vast, ancient and intricate society. There is conflict in a forest, but there is also negotiation, reciprocity and perhaps even selflessness.

items.content_html: This one stings.
items.content_text: This one stings.

items.content_html:
Well, this blew my mind: macintosh.js.

This is Mac OS 8, running in an Electron app pretending to be a 1991 Macintosh Quadra. Yes, it’s the full thing. I’m sorry.

My second Mac was a Quadra 950, purchased in 1991. Twenty-nine years later, here’s an emulator of that beast of a machine running on my MacBook Pro.
items.content_text: Well, this blew my mind: [macintosh.js](https://github.com/felixrieseberg/macintosh.js/). > This is Mac OS 8, running in an Electron app pretending to be a 1991 Macintosh Quadra. Yes, it's the full thing. I'm sorry. My second Mac was a Quadra 950, purchased in 1991. Twenty-nine years later, here's an emulator of that beast of a machine running on my MacBook Pro.

items.title: I miss live music.
items.content_html:
Illiterate Light are one of my top new bands of 2020. Theyâ€™ve just followed up their self-titled debut with a live EP. It makes for bitter-sweet listening.

Two of the new recordings were made here in Nashville, at indie venue Basement East. It was all but destroyed in March of this year by a tornado.

I miss live music. More than that, my heart goes out to all those in the arts struggling to make it through this pandemic.

ğŸµ â€œCarloline Lorelei (Live at The Basement)â€
items.content_text:
[Illiterate Light](https://www.illiteratelight.com/) are one of my top new bands of 2020. Theyâ€™ve just followed up their self-titled debut with a live EP. It makes for bitter-sweet listening. Two of the new recordings were made here in Nashville, at indie venue Basement East. It was [all but destroyed](https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/country/9331573/nashville-responds-tornado-coronavirus-country-music) in March of this year by a tornado.

I miss live music. More than that, my heart goes out to all those in the arts struggling to make it through this pandemic. ğŸµ â€œ[Carloline Lorelei (Live at The Basement)](https://music.apple.com/us/album/carolina-lorelei-live-at-the-basement-east/1523720730?i=1523720734)â€

items.title: The Ritual of Morning Coffee
items.content_html:
I love coffee. Good coffee. If Iâ€™m being honest, Iâ€™m a coffee snob.

Several years ago, my brother gave me the gift of pour-over coffee â€“ all the gadgets needed to make my own amazing cup of coffee at home. A digital scale, a beautiful, Japanese hand grinder, a kettle, and a reusable cone filter. And a pound of Death Wish coffee beans. Life-changing.

More than the delicious cup of coffee that results from my efforts each morning, I love the ritual. I go from sleepily out of bed, to my meditation cushion, to my kitchen.

I fill the kettle with water and place it on the stove. I open the bag and smell the aromatic beans as I pour them into the grinder. I place a cup on the scale and the filter on the cup.

Then there’s something wonderful about the physicality of grinding the beans by hand. The smooth, monotonous motion. It’s meditative. I spoon the ground coffee into the filter and watch the scale until it reads the correct number of milligrams. I wait until the water boils and whistles.

Twenty seconds later, it’s reached the right temperature, and I use the small spout to cover the ground coffee until wet. Another twenty-second wait. Then I pour again until the scale reads the result of 6.5 (as I was taught) multiplied by the weight of coffee grounds. I remove the cup from the scale and the filter full of grounds from the cup.

Et voila! What, to me, is the perfect cup of pour-over coffee. No cream, no sugar. Pure, deep black joy in a cup. Fifteen minutes later, the caffeine if flowing through me, and all is right with the world.

ğŸ–Š â˜•ï¸
items.content_text:
I love coffee. Good coffee. If Iâ€™m being honest, Iâ€™m a coffee snob.

Several years ago, my brother gave me the gift of pour-over coffee â€“ all the gadgets needed to make my own amazing cup of coffee at home. A digital scale, a beautiful, Japanese hand grinder, a kettle, and a reusable cone filter. And a pound of Death Wish coffee beans. Life-changing.

More than the delicious cup of coffee that results from my efforts each morning, I love the ritual. I go from sleepily out of bed, to my meditation cushion, to my kitchen.

I fill the kettle with water and place it on the stove. I open the bag and smell the aromatic beans as I pour them into the grinder. I place a cup on the scale and the filter on the cup.

Then there’s something wonderful about the physicality of grinding the beans by hand. The smooth, monotonous motion. It’s meditative. I spoon the ground coffee into the filter and watch the scale until it reads the correct number of milligrams. I wait until the water boils and whistles.

Twenty seconds later, it’s reached the right temperature, and I use the small spout to cover the ground coffee until wet. Another twenty-second wait. Then I pour again until the scale reads the result of 6.5 (as I was taught) multiplied by the weight of coffee grounds. I remove the cup from the scale and the filter full of grounds from the cup.

Et voila! What, to me, is the perfect cup of pour-over coffee. No cream, no sugar. Pure, deep black joy in a cup. Fifteen minutes later, the caffeine if flowing through me, and all is right with the world.

ğŸ–Š â˜•ï¸
